uE3mgCEIREHxq0vlMRJHsA.text: A beautifully appointed restaurant serving Indian Fusion cuisine.  I was there with group of 12 in a private room.  Service was stellar and the food creative, but far from the level the other reviews I see would seem to promise.  While very good, it won't impress the "foodies" among you.

q4m-4_Zn-YHjiIo0DiJ8VQ.text: We ate at Benares for my stepfather's birthday and it is definitely the place to go for a special occasion. From the moment we walked in, the staff were so helpful and attentive and continued to be so throughout the evening-at times perhaps a little too much, one not totally empty glass was removed on my visiting the toilets.We had the set menu which was absolutely divine and my parents had non alcoholic fruit drinks instead of the complimentary wine, I was jealous of their amazing fruit cocktail which was something else! The flavours were amazingly combined in the most delightfully presented and interesting dishes. An expensive but definitely well worth it restaurant.

xyCONAI73cJCeP3Gwk6-cA.text: Really enjoyed my meal here, chef (Atol Kuchar). Indian fusion food, I have a lovely spiced cod with pea puree and surprisingly a very nice bottle of ENGLISH white wine, as recommended by the waiter. It is a little dark when you first go in but the restaurant is large and you feel as though you have space. Friendly, attentive service. I think there is also a private room. There are quite often offers on at this restaurant.

ykNj7GOfeOXx-i0gjgouOg.text: Been there, its nice place. Food is good but certainly does not warrant the kind of price they charge.My rating:1. 7 out of 10 for authentic food taste2. 3 out of 10 for price.

eD1O1bF_xQab1eI0C7OA0g.text: Grace K below is spot on. This is a very lovely restaurant and the food is solid, but it's not true Indian food and it's shockingly expensive. $100 per person without any drinks is preposterous. I wonder if the people giving this 5 stars have ever been to India?

ewWnOD3re_dxdSdMu8Av_A.text: I'm not really sure I had experienced posh Indian properly until Benares. The service, cocktails, wine and menu are topnotch. Indian flavours are present yet quite subtle and understated. I had the most tender and well cooked venison of my life--I didn't want the meal to end. I can't wait for my next trip back!

Nhtpq7lCZfNfjS2QdCVXvg.text: I book a table yesterday 14/10/2012 at 9pm in Benares restaurant , when I arrived they say its booked for private function , no phone call or email sent beforehand tell me about my reservation was cancelled , that too bad especially at 9pm where it's impossible to book any other restaurant,that's was very disappointing .

ef0eiqEGiRv0h9Vr_D9r0g.text: I think Atul Kochhar has done a great job with this restaurant. The ambiance is extremely eclectic, sophisticated, and sleek. A very nouveau experience to Indian dining, with the menu being built by ingredients based on all parts of India with a very contemporary twist to it. Definitely worth a try if you are in the London area and want some fine Indian food :)

mQI1hZUbBkLVvrG1EPOXkw.text: Elegant, sophisticated interior (I always loved the fountain inside with floating flowers)  welcomes you. Delicious food comes at a price - but you were expectating that no? For me, the Murgh Makhani is a standard - delicious and savory, with warm naan and addictive chutneys. The braised lamb is so yummy - it's hard to choose and you're rarely disappointed. There is an attention to the quality of ingredients that is reflected in the food.

gkSDXhb6Y4FD0-3oq0xtgg.text: Top Notch, very high end. If you have a decent budget and want a great indian meal try this spot.

R-rWfMH-Fpfe6Cjym0AixQ.text: I haven't actually been here since 2008 but the food is amazing. I cant remember everything that I had, but I do remember that every dish was a triumph. What stands out in my mind though is my mixed grill starter. The meat was so beautifully spiced it makes my mouth water just thinking about it. I didnt know it was possible to make mixed grill taste that good. Atul Kochhar actually came out of the kitchen and went around all the tables asking how the food was. Three of us had three courses each and two bottles of wine and it came in at just under £240 which for a Michelin starred restaurant I thought this was very reasonable.

Z1-bD7c9pCYD2WmLeGG3hg.text: Went here with a friend for a special lunch and was blown away by the interesting flavors, presentation and combinations. Everything we had was very high quality, not greasy or heavy at all. The menu was fresh, interesting and we did not find a single "butter chicken curry" type dish. We loved the tiger prawns with cauliflower coulis, the eggplant dish, the pea cakes and just couldn't even touch the nice little desserts they brought for us because we were so satiated.... Very nice, romantic setting, great service and upscale Indian fusion!

q_SzLIm3BFFZjOEGyheroQ.text: I just wanted to say that this restaurant is an absolute must for people who want something extra special and don't mind paying for it-because all the food cooked there is prepared by the first Asian person to have the accolade of winning a Michelin star. I am not going to say anymore other than this.

-vQ1_XuXP0hIy8dZgYWxfg.text: Benares is an uber posh curry. Now let's take stock here, and rewind a little bit. Can you think of an example where what is quintessentially a cheap thing has been done poshly successfully? All that springs to my mind are awful travesties such as designer shell suits, London Black cabs (it's a taxi, get over it) and Burberry check. A posh restaurant is great not because it's posh. Nor is it great because of all the obvious things it must do to justify the ticket price, like a pretty lady at the front and lots of marble within the first 10m of the entrance and designer flower arrangements. You've psyched yourself up for ponying up lots of cold hard cash, and from that point on your mind expects these things. What makes a posh restaurant great is all the little bits someone has painstakingly thought about that you would never think of. Like a waiter helping with your chair, even if you're a man, or a palate cleansing bit in between courses, brought up on a spoon to help enjoy the flavour more. Repeat a request? Never! It's the attention to these little touches which sets a restaurant from the rest, and performs the Jedi mind trick that ends with you saying Please take my money, this was unforgettable, and actually quite good value while coughing up 70 quid or more a head. I've had it happen, and it's great when it does. But sadly not at Benares. Think of Benares as the Burberry of restaurants. Much like making cheap nasty clothes in China and selling them for a packet through successful marketing, Benares takes what is at best a mediocre restaurant experience and tries to present it as something more. Curry was never meant to be this way. The food is no different from an average High Street curry joint, all apart from size of course. God forbid one should have big portions at a posh restaurants - that might eat into the margin. The decor fails the most simple of layout tests - when people pay more, everyone should be able to talk to everyone else at their table without having to shout. If you have to shout, the tables are too close together. Benares is like a stadium. Echoeey, loud and obnoxious. Like a poorly designed call centre automation system, the waiters are great if you know exactly what you want, it happens to be one of the options and you have no questions which require human interaction. Stray off the script at your peril. Have to repeatedly ask for something? Well, it is a very popular curry joint sir. Do yourselves a favour. If you want posh food and service, go somewhere that can provide them. If you don't mind the service and want the best curry you've ever had go to Lahore's in the East End. But why compromise and get the worst of both sides at Benares?

4upRi2xC9Zt1pJVohtAuEA.text: Nice high quality indian food. Cost is on the high side, its indian cooking at its finest. I would go back.

bJ_EGRFxjW1d4GYPDh6yhg.text: Ate here last night while in London.  It has a Michelin star (according to my friend), and I love Indian food so we gave it a go.  Had the Grazing menu which is five courses, along with the premiere wine  accompaniment.  The amuse Boucher was a small puff with yogurt sauce, very bland.  Next course was three small terrines in little glass jars.  The shrimp was good.  The chicken mediocre.  The third was fish (I think?).  Overall it was ok.  Nan bread with honey was very tasty.  next course with small piece of salmon, chicken tikka and lamb chop was excellent.  All 3 were perfectly cooked  and very flavorful.  The wines were very tasty but several of the whites were served at room temperature which I didn't care for.  The atmosphere is very posh, noise level was ok.  Servers were fine but the time between courses was sometimes ridiculously long and the wine pairing often showed up a while after the meal with which it was meant to be paired. The staff was apologetic but at these prices (and with a Michelin star) I expect flawless, which this was not.  Amaya restaurant, in Kensington, is a better bet.  I have Ben there's twice and it was superb both times.  I would recommend Benares, but gave it three stars because it should have been better.

wfr3NtQLfhwsgohVXVPUwg.text: I went here last year for a corporate dinner. The food was excellent--not quite straight indian food, but more like indian-inspired fusion cuisine. The setting was beautiful, very chic with dim lighting. The place is not cheap however: you have to get a started and a main course, according to the menu. That will set you back a minimum of £35 per person before drinks. Yet my group's bar bill came up to more than the food bill! Service was excellent, but you would expect that. I would give the restaurant 5 stars, but I only reserve that for restaurants that fulfil my dual criteria of being excellent, and cheap.

2ZsbY8Sz-HeHiDSKFmwLCA.text: We took both sets of parents for saturday lunch at Benares and everyone thoroughly enjoyed themselves. The fixed price menu was great value and all the options delicious and the wine complimented the food beautifully. The service was friendly and efficient, we will definitely return.

OGuQKchSSEP5nWhw3i_IgA.text: Benares is located in Mayfair next to the Rolls Royce and Bentley show rooms. Upon entry your coats will be taken and you will be led upstairs into the bar, we had a lovely red wine before taking our seat in the restaurant. The decor is what you would expect from a restaurant in this area of London. We dined at 6PM and could have taken advantage of the set menu, however we decided to order from the a la carte menu as the dishes were too tempting, we were not disappointed as all three courses were of an outstanding quality. The staff could not have been more helpful and polite, it really was an enjoyable dining experience albeit an expensive one!

Z4BapOWUCx_CyPTP_hok-g.text: Considered on of the finest, if not the finest Indian restaurant, in London and for a good reason. I loved the food, which was very carefully prepared and it was impossible to resit. The service was professional and pleasant. Many people dress up to go to this restaurant for a dinner. WOULD GO THERE AGAIN! (april 2008)

CVhMSyc-l_LYpaItcjoM4g.text: Four of us went to Benares recently and I enjoyed this Indian Fusion restaurant in the tony Mayfair section. The interior is sharp and opulent and the service was very attentive. We decided to get each of the non-vegetarian entrees and split them all up. In short, here's how I'd rank them: 1. Pan Seared Sea Bass with mushrooms and coconut sauce. **really excellent; perfectly cooked; coconut sauce was a nice compliment without overpowering the fish. Mushrooms were also very tasty. 2. Tandoori Tiger Prawns ** very, very good. Nice spicy rub with big, fresh prawns cooked perfectly. 3. Roasted Deer Fillet ** very tender and superbly favoured. Cooked just right. 4. Marsh Mutton Three Ways ** Great combination of flavors with the Hummus and Chickpeas. 5. Monkfish and Kofta ** Cooked nicely and flavorful. Good for seafood lovers. 6. Tandoori Chicken Supreme ** Good but lentil sprout salad added little; a bit forgetful. 7. Pan Fried Lobster Tail ** Yummy but a very small portion; Need the Naan to mop up the coconut sauce on this one. 8. Mallard Duck Supreme ** A bit tough and fatty but not bad by any means. Duck is duck. Overall, all eight had something to offer and you can't go wrong with any of them. The portions are all pretty small so what I thought was originally overindulgent by ordering the eight ended up not being so at all.

yCHNyWR1stUQb55ipKL9Zw.text: The best thing about this place is the presentation of the food, which was probably what lead it to its michelin star.The starters were incredible. I had the chicken liver which were roasted to perfection. My friends had the soft shell crab, which left me with a case of food envy! It was crispy, yet soft and quite sweet.I had the cod for main. It was presented on a rectangular ceramic plate with a fancy onion jous. Although the cod was spot on, I couldnt work out what made it an indian dish. Similarly, my friends had the venison, monkfish and rogan josh. All stated their food was lovely, but by simply using a spice here and there, we couldnt help but feel a little cheated. The staff were friendly, although i couldnt help but feel they were in excess. When going to the ladies, it was as though they were all lined up to guide us there! Sweet, but possibly a little overkill!Additionally, when my friend ordered the lamb rogan josh from the 'traditional' section, the waiter tried to convince her to have something more adventurous from the 'modern' section. He could have meant well, but his approach was rather agressive than advisory, which quite upset my friend.Overall, it was a nice evening, with the bill coming up to £75 per head for four people, including drinks (of which two were £10 cocktails).

Z6QUn_lABoPE3ZbWcOGdsg.text: Best upscale Indian dining experience I've ever had. You can still see, taste and smell the Indian origins in dishes here, which for some contemporary/ fusion-style restaurants is hard for them to pull off. (Sometimes the only thing Asian about an Asian-fusion Restaurant in the giant Buddha statue one the wall). Maybe the best naan I've ever had. Highlights include the lamb shank. A first class experience.

RmIWpuD8STU-EFd719t5Rw.text: i've never had high-end indian food before, so i was skeptical, but i was pleasantly surprised with how great and high-end the food tasted. the restaurant's decor is also very nice and expensive-looking.i ordered the grazing menu with the table, and although pricey, well worth it. the food is incredibly unique and simply divine.their wine menu is extensive and good - and the amount of care/thought that goes into serving the wine is impressive. the waiter brings out the wine on a table with the wine in it's own carriage, then pours the wine into a decanter. properly swirls the wine around and...etc (other fancy stuff that he was doing, but i can't really explain why he was doing it).anyway - highly recommended.

W8DhsaSzsF6CcU0rqIx9Dw.text: Beautiful food. Definitely deserves the Michelin star.

WQflMurLHawyDphCiWtRaw.text: We went today for a lunch on the 'Fixe Prix' menu and we had high expectations , we were not disappointed. The location is good and entering the restaurant you are made to feel welcome, not a hint of the intimidation you sometimes get in 'posh' restaurants. Make no mistake, this is a posh restaurant, they try hard and are dedicated to flavour. The ambience is good even though it was a Monday lunchtime there were a scattering of other diners and the waiters were attentive and politely friendly. The 3 course menu was with matching wines by the glass and they were well selected and well explained by the wine waiter. The 3 courses showed imagination and were beautifully presented. The tastes were good, sometimes surprising, but all the cooking was just right. We all chose the salmon fishcakes as starter and they were crispy on the outside, moist on the inside and packed with flavour. The main for 3 of us was grey mullet - a difficult fish to cook. It was perfectly cooked and beautifully moist. The sauce was a flavour sensation and the 'Indian style' mash was lovely. For desert I had mango sorbet and vanilla and rum pannacotta - it was again beautiful and tasteful. The meal came with coffee or tea and petit fours which was a relaxed way to end the meal. Even on the fixed price menu the bill was over £40 a head - but I reckon it was great value - wonderful tastes, beautiful presentation, great ambience, really good service. I would go again tomorrow and if you love good food so should you!

7Yg0CBWE2JGtZKWei_Widw.text: Without a doubt, this is THE poshest Indian restaurant I have ever been to.  Beginning with the hostesses downstairs, coat check, the servers, busboys, and sommelier - everything at Benares is topnotch.Wine selection was great, and the I have to say the food was delicious.But - when going to England, after fish and chips, the main thing I am hoping for is mind-blowing Indian food.  Being extremely tight on time for this trip, I only had time to plan 4 meals, and live or die, one of them was going to be Indian, or I was going to refuse to leave the country.That is how I ended up at Benares.  It was supposed to be one of the best, and walking in, I had mixed feelings.  I have never known "amazing" Indian food to come from a place this posh, and my doubts began to build, but this being a business dinner, I also found that I was very please with the ambience.  It was perfect for the occasion.Let's just put it like this. We had a LOT of food - including their famous monkfish dish, but that should have been hint #1.  SInce when do you hear about MONKFISH at an Indian restaurant???Yes, the food is delicious, but this is NOT Indian food.  It's more fusion, with a very Indian twist.  While delicious, it wasn't the "French Laundry" type of delicious, and it wasn't the best in its field as far as I have tried, so I ding it one star to bring it to four stars.Their 3-course fixed menu for dinner is £65 per person.  That is approximately $97.  You can pick a la carte, but there is a minimum of one appetizer and one entree per person.  Given the fact that none of us were interested in Indian desserts - we opted for the latter.  That, combined with 2 bottles of wine, 2 dessert wines, and 2 scotches at the end, came to a whopping £550.  $825, folks.  This breaks down to a $200+ per person meal.  It was good, but it wasn't THAT good.  For business purposes, I would go to Benares again, but NEVER again for my ONE INDIAN MEAL in London.  That was a big mistake, but it was my own fault for not checking into it first.  They have it all for the meat lover and vegetarian, and everything on the menu sounds exquisite.  Excepting the kebab appetizer and the chicken entree that one of us ordered, I thought everything was very tasty - especially the potato pancakes, and my Indian cottage cheese dish.Order the dessert Riesling - - it's a wonderful finish to a good, and extraordinarily expensive meal.  But do remember, I said it here loud and clear - - this is NOT Indian food!

h3hOH9Ar_brZsVu8VOuyqA.text: If you think you have had great Indian food and you haven't been here...you have not had great Indian food.I love Indian food!  I eat it weekly.  In Los Angeles you can find some decent Indian food, in Singapore there some really great Indian restaurants but nothing compares to Benares.It is by far the best Indian food I have ever had.To top it all off I asked my server if they had lamb vindaloo and they did not but they didn't stop there they actually made it.The restaurant is beautiful too.

1JL_i4otMJiRbJqrX_4clw.text: We went to Benares on the evening of May 23, 2013.  Reservation was for 8 PM, they were prepared and took us immediately to the bar.  Very relaxed and good service.  When ready we were taken to the dining room.  The decor is very contemporary and pleasing.  At this point the service became very uneven.  After quite a delay a waiter came and did apologize.  Unfortunately the delays continued for the entire dinner.  Each of us had 2 courses.  They were tasty and well presented.  Quite honestly they were not  dishes that I was familiar with, but I certainly would go back for the food.  Overall this was not a dinner to remember.  It appeared that some patrons received excellent service suggesting that they might be regulars and we were certainly not.

OhXmx0CCJ5GGq_zDYiYUGA.text: I went to Benares the first time in i think it was 2004 for a business dinner and since then try to make this restaurant a stop each time i am in london. everyone always says there is good indian food in the UK and that is true, but the indian food you get at Benares is extraordinary, it is amazing. i am not an idian food specialist and can't say if it is authentic or not ... and i honestly don't care since to me food just has to taste good and at Benares it does it fantastic. i don't remember what i had the last time i was there a couple of years ago, but no matter what just try it ... watch out with the wine, this is london and wines can be really good, but also quite expensive. a couple of things about the place. the service is great, the bar area is great, the design is clean, modern, with a beautiful black pool which usually has some flowers swimming in it. only thing to remember is that the entrance is a bit hidden. the restaurant is not on the ground level and you enter through the main building entrance. but once you are in, you are in food paradise.

pihBAwQnEMixdjaO9TH7XQ.text: I went here last night for a birthday treat and was so impressed. It is run by Atul Kutcher and has a michelin star so my hopes were high and it was so much better than I had imagined. I went for the Prix Fixe menu which was £24.99, amazing value for what you get. The place is so beautiful and the service is fantastic, I would have paid anything for it. To start I had potato cakes with chutney and they were amazing, not oily or crispy like usual but really soft. Then I had the leek and butternut squash gratin for mains which was served in a tomato sauce, so delicious.  We also ordered rice and daal to share between us and got some lovely naan bread with it. I skipped dessert and went for a daquari instead. They have a lovely bar with a huge cocktail menu. You can order bar food there as well in case you're not eating in the restaurant. The tables are all far apart so there is no listening to the loud people beside you thank goodness. Our bill including drinks and service charge came to £88.Couldn't think of a single fault with Benares, it's brill.

photos.caption: Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom

5WiGw964me6APnt9ENOi7Q.text: I went here for a work dinner a couple of weeks ago. The food is really good in terms of taste and presentation, and the service was great and very friendly. However, given the price and the reputation of the place, maybe I was expecting more in terms of the taste of the food? I enjoyed it all but would have liked to be blown away a bit more, taste some fireworks in my mouth, for this amount of money. So only four stars.

SSunE0ngTtGuwzgB50U_Nw.text: Super expensive, but very good. I took my mom here after havin to CONVINCE her that indian food is absolutely delicious (she has problems with the cuisine after a curry episode in her past..nuff said)The ambiance is great, very good for a date. The food is also very delicious.  A modernized version of tradiitonal indian fare, making it palatable for experienced diners and those who are just getting used to indian flavors. Being from the states, going for indian food in london is somewhat of a spectacle but this place definitely made its impression. 2 entrees, naan, and a bottle of wine came out to £98, a bit pricey for dinner but then again so is everything else in london.

r2h17jOLvLjOZ6iewwBhgw.text: Food was average, but the service was below average!. Yes the presentation was good , but that's all. In summary - below average service, average food but good presentation. I have tried few Michelin star restaurants - this one should not be on the list, there are better Indian restaurants in London !

xoHr63jF5cnYyXWB_95ORw.text: This is the Indian food to die for.  I have a talent of booking the place I didn't intend to.  I booked a restaurant in a rush and found myself arriving 5 mins earlier and only to be informed it is not open, then I found out it was Indian (I am not a fan at the best of times).  The staff are fantastic and extremely attentive.  The decor is very up market and the food was just absolutely delicious.  I would recommend the pairing wine, whoever puts it together had just matched the wines with the food just perfectly.  I have just left the restaurant and already booked my next visit.  It is extremely cheap for the quality you get.   The portions are small but you can have a few courses and you do feel quite full afterwards.  Bon appetit.  p.s. arrive a little early, there's a nice bar by the water feature and they have a fantastic cocktail menu.

g4NZx9h4TIIeUSap0r_dGg.text: Oh dear! I had really high hopes for this Indian fusion restaurant which my boyfriend treated me to for our 4th anniversary. Everything started well, we ordered a couple of delicious cocktails and sat in the empty but quite nice bar. we were then seated at our table and decided to go for a. the tasting menu and b. the more expensive 45 year old chenin blanc. Both turned out to be errors. The tasting menu was extremely hit and miss, one of the courses was 3 jars of what i can only describe as horrible tasting fish. one course was delicious (a selection of indian spiced meats). the main course of obligatory curry was meh. The expensive wine was both syrupy sweet and not as nice my the 2011 which would have been a lot cheaper. In a way it's unfair to give benares 2 stars, the home made bread is divine, but after having been to Veeraswami and Amaya, this one falls very short of the mark for me. And for the price you're paying, you should expect the best.

D2zBQ5m1Fw5LDy6asjG9bA.text: Now this is worth the trek. Lunchtime is very family friendly. The food was to my mind 'Indian-fusion' which I found to be agreeable. Staff = goodOverall impression = good value We will rush back soon!

HmqW9wD-OVGhD6ByojswcQ.text: Having heard a lot about this Michelin starred Indian influenced restaurant run by Atul Kochhar (winner of Great British Menu), I decided on Saturday to try it for lunch. The prix fixe menu offers you a choice of three starters, mains and desserts, and costs £24.95 including a glass of wine, coffee and petit fours (£19.95 for two courses). First to come were some mini poppadoms served with a variety of sweet relishes, none of which, sadly, were up to a fiery lime pickle or a sweet mango chutney dished out in every Indian restaurant around the country. Particularly disappointing was the carrot dip. Avoid. However, from this point the experience picked up considerably. The shot of spicy tomato soup was beautifully smooth, and my starter of pepper and fennel crusted squid salad was exquisite. The main of King Fish fillet with chilli garlic mash and coriander sauce was also very good, if slightly dry. My white chocolate mouse pudding with banana and basil sorbet was possibly the highlight. My friend's chicken supreme was possibly a better bet, and came with a lovely makhani sauce. The coffee, too was a little sub-standard. All in all, good value for what you get, but if you want Michelin star dining, I'd stick to Chez Bruce.

mHhenSLIVXRGgNTz-1O2Pw.text: Went with a Brahmin Indian friend who eats no garlic and onions (because they are said to 'excite the senses') and found really excellent Indian cooking with a number of lesser seen dishes such as the superb chettiyar baigan (aubergine). Tawae ke paneer, pyaz ka laccha and the usual dals and aloo are all beautifully executed. Clean, smart decor and smooth and knowledgeable service (there's even a sommelier) make this one of the best Indian restaurants in London. Good for business too - although there's no wi-fi offered (a growing peeve, since with the advent of the iPhone, one often wants to access information quickly when at a business lunch. The network password could be posted on the menu or be freely accessible, as at The Ship on Wandsworth Bridge).

Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. The main restaurant

53JC0_y6WsYXrGcTWV7GPg.text: Service was a bit slow at start but picked up. While the food was lovely, they can't deviate from the menu preparation at all. Liking a bit more spice to our Indian food, we had to request a side of curry to supplement which totally did the trick. I would likely go back again given the ambiance and location but it's behind Veraswamy in my book.

2rVEbgKyYDvnJqobYLCGkQ.text: I suspect my expectations and opinions of this establishment are heavily influenced by my background where I am lucky enough to have first class Indian food at home whenever my mum steps to the hob. Nonetheless I am aware of the fine-dining interpretation of the sub-continent offered here and can vouch for Atul Kochar being a thoroughly nice bloke. But... this should have been better. So much better.The doorman had an unfriendly aspect and did little to make us feel welcome on arrival. The pair of ladies on the front desk were but the first bloom of excess in the restaurant's bloated seasonal staff as we met at least 10 of them during the course of our experience.The amuse bouche was a small potato bhajia on apple salad. The bhajia was overly spiced with cumin and the apple was insipid in its neutered pickling which did little to offset the overbearing hit of cumin - not great. We also had mini poppadoms with a selection of chutneys - apple and ginger, tomato, and finally pineapple. The poppadoms were not cracklingly fresh mastication tended to result in your teeth feeling glued together. The chutneys were fine but all much of a muchness, it would have been good to have one which was more chilli and mustard seed than base notes of savoury with an overly sweet spotlight.Both had the fish sheekh kebab to start and this was lovely - reminiscent of the tandoori crab kebab at veeraswamy - but with a lovely green chutney sauce and side salad. The garlic mayo was served generously whilst the green sauce was spitefully smeared on the plate - a pity because this combined with the spicing of the fish was very tasty.Mai was the sea bass - very well cooked with exquisitely crisp skin but not particulary flavoursome - served in a sauce of raw coconut onion and turmeric with some random courgettes and vine tomatoes... Strange combo! The paratha served with it was lovely and appetisingly brushed with ghee - this tasted like home at least. The problem with the parath and indeed the wine is that it is not served with the food so you have to wait around for the accompaniments which are ameant to compliment the food - sloppy. I had the matched wines for the starter and main and I could not catch the name of the first which was okay but the gewürztraminer accompanying the main was full bodied and vibrant - perfectly matched.Dessert was a lychee kulfi in a milky berry sauce with plastic-textured vermicelli... I am unsure how this dish came to be conceived but the vermicelli proved a weak point as it was poorly executed and incongruous with the falouda-lite nature of the dish. Gulab jamun brulee was billed as a deconstructed gulab jamun - all of the ingredients in the form of a brulee. Unfortunately the main ingredient is milk powder and so the only real taste in the dish was the black cardamaom which was nice enough but only in smaller doses than offered here.Petits Fours were nice but again the cumin was all up in your grill!Overall I am judging this place a bit more harshly but that is because at this level and at this price it should be excellent and it just wasn't. Felt as if a lot of the experience was contrived to eke out more and more money, a flat fee of £5 for sides is steep when you consider you may be charged that for sundries such as naan or even rice - not too clever in an indian restaurant IMHO. Still worth a try if you are curious but I would temper expectations before chancing the threshold.

PvvRU_j3Jo3i8XDb3uuU6w.text: We had to try this place because we were so intrigued by the combination of Michelin stars with 'ethnic' food.  Overall it's a mixed bag.  I usually love tasting menus -- unfortunately here, I cannot recommend it.  Just order a couple of dishes off the menu. I can however recommend getting the wine guy to help choose wines for the dishes you choose, because the wine pairings with the tasting menu were genius.  Within the tasting menu, the tandoori scallops were fantastic.  The duck dish was bland, and the lamb dish was a huge amount of food, which doesn't work for a tasting menu.  the naan was simply sublime (although by the time it came out I was too full to eat it really).Service also had a couple of amateurish missteps you don't expect at a Michelin-starred restaurant.  One example:  the first course of our tasting menu was introduced as the 'amuse' -- which it was not, it was the first course.  Overall, especially considering the astronomical bill -- you might be better off choosing someplace else...

Kd1bCrsbdd3Wxnza2ZbaoA.text: A great location in a great city, that night started very well.I've seldom received such a nice welcome by restaurant staff. It felt very warm, yet always very genuine (unlike some I-am-so-nice-to-you-with-my-big-smile-that-you-can't-leave-without-giving-a-huge-tip waiters in some US diners...).On the other hand, it's the kind of service you'd expect from a Michelin starred restaurant.Once seated in a quiet part of the restaurant, we were handed a very nice cocktail list, with a leather cover. The devil is in the detail they say... The cocktail list itself was a very nice read, although I must say they were slightly over-priced (12£ minimum).The rest of the dinner went very well, the service kept a high level throughout the night, bringing us our food swiftly and reacting well to demands.The wine we selected (South African) was exquisite, and after 20 minutes breathing was a good companion to all of our dishes.The starters and mains (the menu mentions you have to order minimum 2 dishes...) are of great quality. My crab meat was shaped as a crab, and the spicy was never too hot.Likewise, the venison with a bitter chocolate vindaloo sauce could not have been any better cooked or seasoned.However, I kept feeling the prices were slightly exaggerated and exponential (rising quickly from 24£ to 87£ !).Yet the portions were reasonable and we left the restaurant quite satisfied.

14lXSVY5Iwg7ls7rlyHpJA.text: Tonight we didn't experience what I believe to be Benares' finest experience, it was a far cry from what Michelin star inspectors experience.The night started off well with a cocktail in the bar whilst waiting for our guests to arrive. When gathered they too got cocktails and we were shown our table.After 15 minutes we were given the menus, then we were asked 3 times in 10 minutes if we were ready to order!We were given a delightful amuse bouche shortly after ordering.The starters arrived promptly and the soft shell crab was certainly very good.The starters were cleared and the main course arrived in good time, except for the dall, we asked about this to be told it was just coming. We waited a moment then decided to start. We were over half way through when we asked again for the dall... ...it's just coming! By the time it arrived we'd almost finished.Pretty full we decided to skip desert and have a tea.The tea took over 30 minutes to arrive, when it did it was wrong, they had to take it back. 10 minutes later they brought the correct teas.After tea we asked for the bill, 10 minutes passed before it arrived. We immediately got our cards out to pay. Someone came with the card machine, a waiter smashed a glass and the guy with the card machine disappeared. He then collected payment from 2 other tables so we got up and walked to the bar to pay.This is not the service you expect at a Michelin starred restaurant, especially one work over a waiter per table head count. Needless to say at £100 per head they didn't get the £50 optional service charge!The food is up to the billing the service is worse than Pizza Hut.

q8N7Iww-jvez0mirE8ugoA.text: Our local Indian chef and restaurant owner Raj of Indian Ocean in Centreville, VA recommended Benares to us when we told him we were traveling to London.  I think this may have been my first dining experience at a Michelin star rated restaurant and it did NOT disappoint.   We went there for lunch (3 hour lunch) and they did not rush us or hurry us in anyway.  We started at the bar for a cocktail and the cocktails were amazing!  We were then seated in the dining room.  Great space and not noisy.  Everything we had was really good.  I went for non-traditional Indian and had the lamb which was fantastic!  The wine list is amazing! Can't wait to go back but need to save up for this type of an experience!

i1Zj6XxJxIhKgVoTukm-Mg.text: We stumbled on this place through Yelp.  Very modern, upscale restaurant.  We asked the waiter to recommend all the dishes because everything looked amazing.  We had a ravioli appetizer which was a great suggestion as well as a 3 chicken dish with many great flavored.  For the main we had a lamb curry, chicken tikka masala and two vegetable dishes.  All were very very good!!  This was one of our more enjoyable meals in our 2 week trip to London.  We will definitely go back.

eJQIjpcb3EeUVWxErkBzoA.text: I was really struggling with whether to give Benares two or three stars. It was a nice meal and with 35£ for a three course set menu, value for money. The Michelin star however raised expectations (so perhaps this is not fair as I would have rated differently without it). Having traveled in India, both north and south, I have had food that blows your socks off; and being anywhere else than the UK I would have forgiven mediocre Indian food. However, in the town where Tikka Masala is called a national dish, I expect to have the best.About the food: We started off well with some small round Papadams accompanies by three different chutneys: Pineapple, apple and tomato.  Especially the spicy pineapple chutney was great and a good start to a fusion Indian meal. The starters, two different types of kebabs, were acceptable with clear notes of India merged in nice presentation of the food. Especially the fish kebabs were delicious with yummy chili mayonnaise and pickles. It was the main dish that dropped the mood. The chicken with lentil sauce I ordered was dry and dull in taste. Nothing like the juicy, soft chicken you get in India, or at least a good Indian restaurant. If something, Indians know how to make their chicken. The Naan bread that was served as a side was also dry, and where was the butter? I like my Naan soaked in lovely grease, but in this case the naan was plain and tasteless! By now, I'm sure many fans of the restaurant think that I should have gone to Tooting for my meal, and I agree =). This was clearly just not my thing. Well it gets a bit better from here, the dessert was great . It was a chocolate ball, housing a lovely chocolate mousse with raspberries on the side. Not too sweet, but full and creamy. The presentation was also very impressive, very beautiful. Taste-wise I would give it five stars, but it had nothing to do with India. Also the dessert enjoyed by my date, apple crumble, was far from matching the theme. I had a peak at the A La Carte list and there the desserts seem to (at least the names and descriptions) have more in common with the appropriate cuisine, so perhaps it was a punishment for going for the set menu. We also got some lovely pralines to finish the meal.About the drinks: I am not a fan of pairing wine with Indian (or other spicy) food, so went for a nice Cobra beer. I was a bit disappointed that there was only two beers on the drinks menu: Cobra and something else I just cannot remember. With a rising boutique beer industry, I would have hoped for more selection. The cocktails served to the tables next to us looked however yummy. If not for an early morning the next day I would have continued with  a nice Mumbai Martini or a Masala Sour =).About the service: The service was very friendly. There were quite many different waiters serving us, but it did not seem to take the quality down. In the end however, we had to wait for the bill quite long. We had arrived early for dinner (6:30pm) and the restaurant was now filling up, and you could really see the effect. When we finally got our bill, there was annoyingly an extra charity charge included. I have nothing against charity, however I appreciate if I am asked before if I would like to contribute. It felt a bit like someone was trying to trick me by sneaking the 1£ in (I'm sometimes a bit lazy to look at anything other than the end sum). Regardless of the small sum, we asked the charity to be removed, which is not that nice to do.All in all, the experience was not too bad, but clearly not to my taste. I would not go to Benares again, but in case someone is interested, I would recommend choosing bits and pieces from the A La Carte list. The set menu was value for money, however not the most authentic experience if you are looking for something special.

cJPQ71wBxI5gArLaPFIswQ.text: This place lives up to its Michelin star. Excellent service, well thought out dining room and great food. I would say its overpriced, especially as a vegetarian. Friends who were with me said their meat dishes were some of the best they've had.They did make me a special dish that wasn't on the menu without any problem at all. Staff were AL very helpful and pleasant. Thoroughly enjoyed the chutneys that came with the poppadoms. Apple one is especially delicious.

UHcSfI-FYY-3KAetcJJ9Bg.text: Amazing cocktails! The bartender are stellar.  We had a beautiful table, but the service was the only reason I docked a star.  It's usually really great, this last visit it was a little spotty.  But the food was wonderful!

LVFadOC5rmchy5iWY7KrYg.text: I go to Benaras on every trip to London, despite the fact that there are only a couple of vegetarian entrees on the menu. However, those dishes have been exceptional. My local cronies rave about the fish - some of the best they have had. I obviously cannot comment first hand on that, so I will take their word for it :-) Atul has written a book on that, so there goes...This is a Michelin starred place, so it has all the trappings that you can expect from that rating.

UHANPd2GmVoG2ajrAtobCQ.text: Incredible Indian fusion. NOT traditional Indian food so if that's your yearning, this is not your spot.Fantastic service, knowledgeable sommelier that will help to pair wine with each course, or recommend a bottle that will compliment your full meal selelctions.Very inventive fusion dishes and exquisite chutneys, everything made fresh to order.  The subtleties in the spicing is really amazing - not strong and direct like traditional Indian food, but very fresh and distinctly flavorful. I have had Indian fusion in Mumbai, Toronto and Vancouver.  This definitely ranks up at the top of my list. Mango chili mojito was to die for, made fresh before our eyes with real mango pulp and fresh crushed chili peppers.Chic atmosphere, lots of beautiful people, so don't wear sneakers.  And book a reservation.Courses are small; don't be concerned about ordering too much.

BKpoeNULV3ues-Sl9WwI-g.text: High --end Indian food in Westend. Went on expenses.. We had the tasting menu for GBP69 a head which, with a couple of drinks will get you just inside your GBP100 entertainment limit. Great food, service good, we couldn't really finish all the food. Have no problem going back sometime.

LYnp054Vx5wKARHaGOZd0w.text: I would give this restaurant 5 stars but I haven't been to a lot of indian fusion restaurants and I can't really compare. My wife and I are big fans and will definitely return.  Please note, this is not a traditional Indian restaurant and does not serve typical Indian fare. So don't come looking for chicken tikka masala and saag paneer here.  This is an eclectic variety of food, made by an extraordinarily talented chef.  I suggest the tasting menu if you can afford it. However if you are in this restaurant you probably can afford it.  The wait staff is great and attentive. The wine selection is wide and with all price points.  Be prepared to try something new. Be adventurous and enjoy the atmosphere. Please make reservations.

Pf75K_GgQQPllssvyj3HaA.text: Expected more from this upscale Indian restaurant. Maybe the problem is it feels, to me at least, that it is trying too hard. But in retrospect, it was one of the first haute cuisine establishments, trying to show Indian food is more then a curry and in a more continental light. And there are some unique dishes. Overall I felt the place a bit almost clubby in decor and where well heeled tourists go for an elegant meal. But if you want to impress someone with a fancy Indian eatery, this place fits the (large) bill.

19de3mUCTBAscqVYpaR_HQ.text: I feel like this place is a bit dated--maybe a bit too early 2000s.  Walking through the empty bar playing musac-style music was a bit depressing, and the decor just seems a bit out of touch with a modern restaurant.  I felt that the expensive food (and it is extraordinarily expensive) was to compensate the glam location, the not used ground floor, and the very very empty bar on a Thursday at 9:30pm.  It was also annoying that we had to book for 9:30, arrived at 9:15 and our table was ready and there were lots of empty tables around us.The food was good, although we ended up opting for a bunch of appetizers as the mains weren't that appealing.  (We also don't eat mushrooms so that eliminated a large number of dishes)  We enjoyed a soft-shell crab appetizer, cauliflower parcels, tikka masala pie, and a trio of a prawn, chicken sausage and lamb chop.  It was all very tasty and interesting.I found it weird that my sauvignon blanc was practically room temperature--maybe I am an idiot when it comes to wines, but I had it put on ice for a bit to chill it down.  And none of the desserts appealed to us--which was a disappointment.We also had a hard time understanding the waiters from many different countries.  I think this place has had its day--time to revamp it a bit.

VsM6sJVRWOoI3JBIuFQpqA.text: Surprisingly disappointing. Mixed performance on service, over-priced food, and tastes that left me wanting. Don't get me wrong: the cuisine here is good. Chicken Tikka Pie was an inventive take on the traditional Anglo/Indian favorite. But for the price I was paying, I expected more than just an interesting idea: the filling was dry, the dish devoid of an accomapnying sauce that could have made it exceptional, the crust itself slightly overcooked. Similarly, my Romney Mutton "Three Ways" could easily have been more than it was: again, it felt a little bit like a sauce problem, where garnishes didn't add to the meat as much as they could have. I ordered some spicy tomato chutney to help round out the meal (and paid handsomely for it...), but it came too late and was relegated to Naan dipping sauce.For a Michelin 1* that charges 30+ GBP for mains, I expect more. I expect attentive, consistent service - and did not receive it. I expect food that is both creatively conceived and well executed. I'm only starting to get to know the higher-end British Indian scene, so perhaps my expectations are too high (and I'll have to revise this review upwards in a few months) - but I've got to think that Benares could have been better. We'll see. In the interim, 3*.

-uOaXoTPfBRGHD-LKsNTyQ.text: It probably says it all that it's located between a Bentley dealership and a RR dealership?!  We checked our umbrella in at the front desk and walked upstairs to the main dining room.  The restaurant was very noisy walking up the stairs and was told there were two parties taking place but we quickly moved past the crowds and to our table.  The capacity of the dining area seemed large and was full.  We started our meal ordering lassi's, which were terrific!  We shared appetizers and naan and had a terrific meal and dining experience.  How many Indian restaurants have you been to where the chef signs his name on the front page of the menu?  For me, not many if any!!!!  This one did.  The menu was two pages in total and offered a small selection of unique dishes relative to my experiences with other Indian restaurants.  This is not the place to go expecting to find "Chicken Vindaloo" or some other regular Indian dish.  I recommend looking at the menu on the internet before dining to make sure you see something that entices you.  Our waitress was attentive but not overly so; however, she forgot to bring our coffee when we ordered a trio of Kulfi (not a big deal).  The meal ended with our waitress placing a small plate with two round white mounds between us and pouring clear liquid over them and we watched in amazement as they started to expand.  As we reached forward to pick them up to taste them the waitress smiled and said they are our hand towels (aka "magic towels!"), which was awesome!  Definitely a great experience and a place I would highly recommend and revisit. NOTE: we were originally recommended to go to Amaya's but waited to long to make reservations.  The concierge mentioned it is Tom Cruise's favorite Indian restaurant in London so who knows!?!?

qr7ea0EcEiHH_6j5rBnjjg.text: Before heading to Benares, I'd seriously advise heading down to your local Indian a few days beforehand. A week before my visit, I'd had a perfectly pleasant, tasty meal at a thoroughly decent curry house in my area. It made me appreciate just how good Benares is. From the mini-poppadums to the delicious kulfis, this place is an absolute triumph. In my head, I keep a note of the best places I've ever eaten. This makes it into the top three. It's hard to talk about the food without going into raptures and dribbling a lot at the thought of eating it again. It's a wondering my keyboard hasn't given up the ghost with all the moisture I'm dripping onto it Our starters of fishcakes with mushy peas were delicious and light but with a neat tang that wasn't overwhelming and set us up nicely for the mains. Chicken tikka leg was infused with a fantastic array of flavours that played merrily on your tongue while the sea bass ranks among the finest treatments I've experienced with this fish. Add to this the aforementioned Kulfis and it was perfection from start to finish. What's more, special praise has to be reserved for the exceptional service. One of our party has a tricky set of food allergies to cook around. Despite being on a London Restaurant Week deal, the staff were incredibly helpful, ensuring that we knew exactly what was and wasn't safe, and going out of their way to help change any of the dishes that needed changing. In many years of restaurant and pub visiting I've never experienced service quite as helpful in such a high end restaurant as Benares. As we paid the bill, and said, politely, that we'd love to return, our waiter helpfully pointed out which meals wouldn't affect the allergies. Not that there was any question about returning some day, anyway, but it's little things like this that, combined with the food, make Benares a winner.

kWhQlDY-8ng_0ASiTXsgpg.text: Located in the heart of Mayfair, this Indian restaurant is now one of my favourites. What surprised me was that the decor was neutral (no bright colours) there was no Indian music playing in the background, which made the restaurant in my opinion more refined/elegant. Although it was only a Wednesday night, the place was fully booked (a sign of a good restaurant). The service was exceptional, no pretentious/in your face waiters. We ordered a selection of dishes, which were all delicious, the dessert was the only thing that I didn't care for (and I have a sweet tooth!). As we had the tasting menu, what was really nice was that when the waiters served each dish, they explained what it was (you also get a glass of wine with each course, but I couldn't comment on that as I don't drink alcohol!). As we were leaving, one of the waiters showed us what the chef's table was like (it's a room for 6 people with two glass walls allowing diners to see the kitchen team at work) - would be perfect for a special occassion. Good night, and would definitely go again.

cTIFA7BoZIpurqKT34a26w.text: I loved this whole experience. The atmosphere is beautiful and comfortable, the service excellent.  The menu is varied and the wine list very good.  London has a lot of less expensive Indian restaurants, but this one is worth it for the overall experience.  Looking forward to going again when back in London.

2--PcGLY_I3EWaauqyLhZQ.text: You can spend your money at better places :(What I liked...Very nice reception with coats and bags conveniently tucked away. They patiently explained the dishes.What was average / barely above average...The food selection..I wanted a fish preparation but everything they had on the menu did not feel Indian. For example, their chargrilled tandoori fish is marinated in coconut milk....Not in a spice marinade. I was expecting a Mumbai style tandoori pomfret with a delectable spicy flavoring, but per the description it felt too westernized.Anyway, they were kind enough to do a custom fish curry for me which was pretty good....But nothing exceptional.Also, they served my beer with ice in it....I mean, seriously people, you are in the UK...How can y'all do that.Anyways, they changed my beer thrice, at which point I gave up, drank a bit and walked away.Overall, not worth a 60 GBP / $75 meal in London. #Meh

photos.caption: Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. Beer with Ice :-(

B_YLOl6MunVnCGKUM20Llg.text: So first time here having seen Atul Kochhar on the tv on many occasions I was very excited to actually go to this resturant.The actual setting was very easy on the eye and very well polished from the time we went through the front door to the time we left. The lady on the door was very polite and well turned out. The decor has its light and dark areas and unlike some restaurants is not so dark you cannot see the person across the table without leaning over and I always find that to be a plus. The background sounds were not intrusive so definitely no shouting to be done to have a conversation.We had a very nice champagne cocktail to start with along side the mini popadoms and a selection of dips to go with them. As to be expected in an establishment of this nature there was a waiter to take your wine order and a different one to take your food order. It was quiet when we arrived as we were their for lunch so perhaps that is why by the time we left we had been looked after by at least four different waiting staff, but it was not a problem as none were intrusive and it never affected our order.Whilst the portions are not large they most certainly hit the spot for both taste and quantity. For some people out their the first two courses would have constituted a meal (we had a four course meal ) surprisingly for an Indian resturant the deserts were very good.All in all I would definitely go back and try something else on the menu as what I had was all very tasty. The only downside I guess is that the main man was no where to be seen . I guess everyone gets a day off at some stage.

photos.caption: Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. Bar area
Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. Petit four

2IsXJrOzP3718iFIwD-85Q.text: Best Lobster Biryani on the planet ! I've had my fair share all over !! Perfect taste and perfectly cooked !!! One star missing is for a bit chaotic service, but it could be because it was a new year eve packed house...but still left us longing for better service to match with the amazing food the kitchen was putting out all night.

fVbdwkYNwkeAAHejo9_01w.text: Located in the least expected area, a hidden gem but food is pretty over priced. Presentation is excellent like you'd expect in any Michelin Star restaurant. If your lucky you can meet Atul, the renowned chef himself. We took our best freind there for his birthday and enjoyed it thoroughly. Mocktails are 10 out of 10 and so is the chicken tikka for starters despite only get two minuscule pieces. Good experience but portions are tight.

photos.caption: Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom

WoKOwA0Qeb770ycuC1U9ug.text: Oh dear. It seemed like the Benares emperor wasn't wearing any clothes on Saturday eve. I was excited to go and try the private dining experience at Atul Kochhar's place for one of my best mate's birthdays, and indeed the room itself, like the rest of the restaurant, looks beautiful. Classy black lacquer with red and gold trimmings, and some dark pretty fretwork separating us from everyone else. We were in the largest room with about 24 people but I believe it can seat up to 36ish and there are other smaller rooms available too.The service is unobtrusive in a good way (i.e. not just absent!) and feels nicely personalised, as they knew the seating plan in advance and thus people's choices between the veg or non-veg set menu. Starters were individually plated; the plaintain kebab was delish and left me wanting more, whilst the salmon was just average in terms of flavour. Main course was more generous portion-wise as it was served family-style to share, but nothing actually stood out taste-wise for me. And that's even after looking past the 'my mum could make this at home for a fraction of the price' type snobbery that I'm sure a lot of asian people get when eating at high-end asian places. My mum could have made it at home for a fraction of the price *and* many multiples more flavourful!If I was choosing the best of the average bunch it would be the kadhai paneer dish, but overall I was disappointed that none of the food excited me. Well the 'chocolate rasmalai' dessert did in name, but turned out to be standard plain rasmalai with choc ice cream on the side. The cherry on top of the disappointment was when the bill was split equally, which I'm usually fully in favour of for simplicity, plus few things make me as painfully uncomfortable as people who squabble down to the last few quid, but not when it turned out others were ordering £60 bottles of wine. In hindsight I should totally have got involved with that. 3-course set menu of at-best-average food (£52pp) plus a glass of wine plus a mint tea and I paid £80. Ouch.I wouldn't blame the restaurant for the bill-splitting carnage but even at the standard set menu price I think this place needs a serious reality check. I'm being generous with a third star for the place being so lush and the service being on point, but I have experienced far, far better.

AltbXcJaiHByKyMc4DwmBw.text: Awesome Indian food near Piccadily, if I lived in London I would come here all the time. It's pricey but super good. The service is good and their bar/lounge area is nice, but they don't serve food at the lounge. Try their chicken tikka and garlic naan!

photos.caption: Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka masala and garlic naan

ULWOUw2dC-ajAW0RtsxjBg.text: The interiors are stunning, food is ok, service is fine. But for a restaurant that boasts 10 years of Michelin stars, I was expecting more. A lot more. When it comes to Indian food, you can do a lot worse, of course. But at these prices, you can also a do a lot better.In a city like, say, Warsaw, this place would be the talk of the town and worth the full 5 stars. But  in London you need to bring a much better game if you're doing Indian food. (No offense to Warsaw, of course).

GKqeSNK2fGsZAGFMQrRvMA.text: I booked this place 2 months in advance for my better halfs birthday, and cause he's allergic to a few things, I went overboard with the emails and phonecalls to confirm everything. On the day of arrival we were greeted by the lovely staff team who kindly took our coats and wet brollys. Sat at the bar and enjoyed a few drinks before being seated in the dining room.Started off with a glass of Laurent Perrier champagne which is my absolute fave, finished that like it was water. The waitress then came for our second order and ordered the Passionfruit Chutney Martini (benares signature created by the chef himself) and the Bollywood. Passionfruit chutney martini was beautiful, strong but appetising, However the Bollywood, if you like your drink strong, then i'd highly recommend this. I could not finish it as it was just a tad too much for me! For starters we ordered Murg Tiranga - Trio of Free Range Chicken: Tikka, Chutney Grilled, Crispy Wing, Paneer Tiranga - Cottage Cheese Three Ways and corn fritters. Before our starters was served we received our Amuse Bouche - Seasonal Vegetable Shami, Mulligatawny Soup. Loved the amuse bouche, what a nice way to start the meal off, light, gets you in the mood for all the food to arrive. I loved all our starters, especially the paneer which came with little pipettes with chutney in them. The chicken was cooked to perfection, loved the tikka, and the wing, however, not so much the grilled - tasted slightly weird and off. The amritsari corn fritters are a nice way to end the meal with a little bit of spice, the black salt really helps ooze all those flavours and blend into one. The service throughout was very attentive, the waiters had remembered my other half allergies, water was always topped up, not too intrusive, we got to enjoy a beautiful meal properly, just the way it should be.For mains we ordered Aloo Benares - Tempered Baby Potatoes, Asafoetida, Cumin and Ginger and Dal - Dal Makhni or Tempered Yellow Lentils with buttered naans. Good portions, not overloaded in a big bowl, definitely enough for two. The best dal makni I have had by far, the aromas took me back to India. The aloo benares didn't quite hit the spot, but it was a good accompaniment to have on the table. Table was cleared up quickly and ordered dessert, my favourite part of the meal :) and chose the Dark Chocolate Mousse, Passion Fruit and Hot Chocolate Sauce, which is basically a chocolate sphere, inside that sits Vanilla Gelato and Chocolate Mousse. Smeared on the plate a passionfruit puree, with passionfruit pate de fruit and a few berries sitting nicely. The waiter poured the hot chocolate sauce on top of the sphere and slowly but surely it melted gracefully, opening the mousse and gelato for our viewing. Definitely the best dessert on their menu, if you want a perfect ending, this is it!!! And yes it tasted amazingly delicious, hats off to the pastry chef, everything was paired perfectly!!! If you like Indian food, this is definitely the place, its not mums cooking, but its a modernised, refined version. I loved it, and so did my other half. Definitely will be returning one day soon.

zmiiwChB2O-4QjzQi9db3g.text: Always good Indian food. Despite I am not a big fans of Indian food. But Benares really is the best I've ever tried. Serving Indian food in a western way.

Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. Seafood platter

qxP61QpY6p3H3LhgAhVE-Q.text: I came here on a recommendation from a local chef, whom I got to know a little bit. We discussed how Indian food had been so assimilated into British life that chicken tikka masala is now considered a national dish of the UK. Naturally, after so much talk, I was craving Indian food, and so he recommended this place that is one of his favorites, which has a really unique twist on Indian food.Details:1) Came for a pre-show dinner, reservation seating @5.30p. 2) Ordered the 2-course prix fixe meal (29 GBP) - a little pricey. 3) Sipped on a refreshing glass of Gewurztraminer while I absorbed the ambiance of the restaurant.YAY -- It's all about the food:1) Amuse bouche - spinach cake stuffed with apricot with mild green chutney. Who doesn't love a delicious freebie?2) Papadum with chutneys (gooseberry, spicy tomato, and mango). I had to consciously stop eating these or I would ruin my dinner. 3) 1st course - cauliflower assortment. I never thought I would get so excited over cauliflower, but every bite of this amazing assortment was packed with flavor: white cauliflower roasted with parmesan, purple vinegar cauliflower, cauliflower puree, and pickled cauliflower. YUM.4) 2nd course - roasted sea bream with masala chips, basmati rice, lentil soup, and whole wheat naan.UGH --Not so great on the service:Service here is off, uncoordinated, inefficient, etc. When I was seated, the waiter made multiple interruptions, like 4-5 trips, just bring menus and water. 2 separate waiters waited on me at first and didn't communicate with each other beforehand. Then by the end of the dinner, I didn't have any specified waiter at all, and I had to wave someone down to get the check. All in all, there just needs to be some level of consistency with the service to have a really fabulous experience. So why 4 stars? Because the food was just that good. Really. I would go back for the food, and more of it!

Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. 1st course: Amazing cauliflower assortment
Photo of Benares Restaurant & Bar - London, United Kingdom. Dining area

The starters were amazing, I would absolutely recommend the samosas and the lamb! The service was ok, would have expect a bit more considering the price you pay.
