bziyiH0uQkV916-9466TCg.text: What's there to say? Chef's table. Tasting menu. You need this in your life. I'm not going to describe the food. Go try this yourself. One day you'll be dead and your soul will meet St. Peter. If he finds out you haven't been to Benares he'll be sending your ass to hell. Do it.

wGB3ISLlCwMNSo3ES1O2Lw.text: Outstanding Indian food with Attitude- by far the best Indian I've eaten.The soft shell crab is delicious and perfectly prepared. The service is very attentive and professionally trained.**Noise level is medium to High.The decor has a glamorous modern feel with perfect lighting.

T6Zd5XpN0o4L5dbPC5LHxQ.text: My husband and I came here for NYE recently and were really looking forward to it and were really bummed to leave it less than thrilled.  The food was tasty, but not worth the cost and was not actually very exciting nor creative.  While the cocktails were pretty, there was no alcohol in them...I am usually a lightweight when it comes to booze, yet, I could not tell that I'd had any alcohol after 2 cocktails.Another thing, for being such a highly regarded luxury restaurant, I'd expect them to know what time our reservation was for and to know whether or not there is time for us to sit at the bar before our meal (on our way to the table, the staff member asked if we wanted to sit at the bar for a drink first, but then when we asked if there was time for that, he asked us what time our reservation was for and realizing it was too late to sit at the bar, he then said nevermind, we better get you seated).  Not that I especially wanted to go to the bar, but it's just a small detail....you know, offering your clients something but then not being able to let them partake in it.Also, I only recently figured out I have a parsnip allergy that makes it hard to breathe and it didn't occur to me that an Indian restaurant would have parsnips on the menu, so I didn't mention anything when my husband made our reservation.  However, when I saw the menu included parsnips in the tasting menu, I mentioned this to the waiter and he quickly said, "are you really allergic to them or you just don't like them?" He clearly didn't believe me, which made it awkward.  Overall, I think I was turned off b/c the service wasn't incredible and the food was way overpriced.

6_QqxWG_1-zlnVYTH9tQ2Q.text: Pretty solid restaurant, though I expect much more of a Michelin star bearing one.  I'm always nervous about eating at an upscale desi (south Asian) restaurant, as a desi American who finds the most satisfyingly authentic food at restaurants with failing health inspection grades; but I was generally happy with the experience at Benares. I came here with a large group.  Full disclosure, I was not paying, and I don't think I would come back on my own dime (just too pricey for what you get food wise). We had our own private dining area which was very pretty, and intimate. The service was quite attentive and helpful with recommendations and questions about the menu. What I especially liked was that though not catering primarily to a desi audience, the restaurant wasn't sort of "sanitized" of its desiness. I spoke to the staff in Urdu, and they were all well-informed of the cuisine and made separate suggestions for palates more experienced with the cuisine. The food was good. - Seekh kabaab appetizer-- yummy, big portion, good texture, but not anything special- soft shell crab appetizer - delicious, nice texture and flavors, unusual dish but highly recommend- chicken tikkah - shared a whole chicken tikkah with one other person; the chicken was juicy and well cooked, but I think the seasoning was a bit lacking, and I wasn't blown away - bread- paratha was all right, but I thought it was the weakest item we tried. they brought us whole wheat and regular, as well as some naan. The paratha wasn't super buttery and flakey as it should be, but decent. The awesome thing was that they had a gluten free bread option for our gluten intolerant diner. - side dishes: we also had some daals and veggies which were good but not memorable (I actually can't remember what we got)- dessert - had the kulfi three ways; it was okay. Overall, though I had a good experience and the food was fine, I found the restaurant to be underwhelming.

edJjnMJWbDEEUVF1LwMJyQ.text: Have been twice and service was terrible on both occasions. Today's visit lasted 20 minutes. This was the amount of time I patiently sat waiting for someone to acknowledge I was seated. Nothing. I don't think they cared much that I left either. I walked right past the two people that seated me - neither cared to inquire as to why I was leaving so soon.  Amazed this place has a Michelin star. There are many other restaurants in the area so no chance I will return a third time.

AcubaN5jTNugCPyf-nit6w.text: Managed to get a Saturday night table for 2 at 10:30. Had cocktails in the bar before going through to the restaurant. Staff very friendly and although clientele was all reasonably smart, the place did not have a stiff feel to it. One starter and a couple of mains were ordered. Soft shell crab starter was very nice as were the guinea fowl and sea bream mains. I have to say the dishes could have been a little bit spicier (hot) for us. I think even someone who didn't like spicy dishes could have eaten what we ordered without a problem. Nice place, nice food, nice staff.

HZok9BviDaDmtUUhNg1ppw.text: Ever get the sensation that you're the last sane person in a world that's gone slightly cuckoo? That's what I felt after browsing the online reviews after dining at Benares. A couple of friends and I, desperate to escape the annual treadmill of office Christmas lunches in perfectly satisfactory but uninspiring chain restaurants, booked a table at Benares and ordered the tasting menu. Not unreasonably, we were expecting quite some meal for our £86 per person (excluding drinks). Indeed, as I sit here typing, I'm catching up with an episode of Masterchef, Sean Pertwee's sandy tones emphasising that for this kind of money, diners expect perfection. What we got was an expensive reality check. Listed as a 7 course menu, it's actually only five courses - the Spinach and Apricot tikki was barely large enough to count as an amuse bouche, and personally, I've never eaten anywhere that lists the palate cleansing sorbet as a separate course (and nor would I want to). Pleasant enough but hardly revolutionary, it set the tone for the rest of the evening. The softshell crab in the second course, was probably one of the best dishes of the meal, but nothing I haven't had elsewhere, and the fripperies on the plate (apple jelly prime among them) appeared to be the product of fancying up the plate, not an integral part of the dish. The subsequent chicken dish was again fine, albeit underseasoned in places, and desperately crying out for an accompanying carb - and I wasn't happy to find myself chewing through some cartilage. The salmon dish, as tiny and bland as its predecessors, was saved by a rich curry sauce and (finally) a (dessert) spoonful of gratefully received rice. It wasn't until the penultimate course (lamb rump, chickpea masala sauce and a samosa, with a side of black dahl) that we were finally served a reasonable portion of food. The small but well cooked hunk of lamb and parathas were most welcome, but accompanied by a masala sauce that was not just under- but badly seasoned, and hadn't been cooked out long enough. By the time the dessert showed up (a rose and raspberry confection with yoghurt and crunchy freeze dried raspberries, albeit accompanied by something parading as, but oh so far from pistachio burfi) miserly portion, but easily the best dish of the day).Even setting aside the paucity of the portions and the chronic underseasoning, the rest of the experience was grinding enough to leach us of our Christmas spirit - the disinterested waiters (verging on the rude - at times they were pretty much throwing cutlery and plates down on the table), the endless wait between courses, the watermarks and thumb prints on the plates and the food and so, endlessly, on. These might sound like persnickety things to pick up on, but at £125 a head I am, frankly, baffled by the whole experience. Even having become irked enough to tell the waiter point blank that the burfi served with the dessert course was inedible (stale chewing gum is the closest we came to describing it), we were met with aloof indifference. I have tasted some magnificent Indian cooking in my time, professional and homemade, and I wouldn't rank this experience anywhere near them. Not only am I unable to comprehend how that was a Michelin starred experience, I am downright flummoxed as to how Benares has clung on to even one star - I've had infinitely superior service and tastier meals at my local eateries. I'm certainly done with Mr. Kocchar's establishments, and frankly the Michelin system if they're content to dole out stars for such mediocre fare.

kFQ9klsZlb0VY89OoikHBQ.text: I want to hate this place; I really do. Why? Because it could seem pretentious, because the idea of Indian Fusion makes the hair on my neck rise, because it's above a Rolls Royce and Bentley dealership; because the bar at the top of the stairs looks like an empty, Vegas lounge bar that is no longer in vogue, or maybe even because I work in the same building and I'm looking for an excuse not to blow the expense account.The thing is, I don't.The food is fun, interesting and good. The Pisco sours are excellently mixed (i.e., the barman seems to know what he's doing). The chicken curry is delicious. The tandoori John Dory fish is normally served on the bone, but they will gladly de-bone it for you, and it tastes amazing. The nan is delicious.Is it over priced ? Yes, absolutely?Is it good ? Yes, absolutely?Is it good value; that's up to you to make up your mind. For me it isn't, but as a few reviewers below, I'm biased; my mom makes Indian food, so I don't go actively seeking Indian fare when I'm out dining. However, I'll give it 4 stars, for proximity to the office, excellent service, decent food (providing you make the right choice), and good drinks menu.

hizT8Wik8vBKhUTMNTRdMw.text: Was there for dinner - quite pricey restaurant but I was fully satisfied. The setting is quite pretty but people welcome everyone saying namaste which I found it weird. I had a set meal for £35 and rest of the table had a la carte. The starters were all average. Think it is not really their strength and they are not the greatest of value.., would skip unless there's something you really like to try. Main dishes are really tasty. I had quail with rice on the express menu and others had chicken two ways and duck vindaloo. They were all very well seasoned with lovely spices. We thoroughly enjoyed it. They were all good portions as well. Even without starters, I would have been full. Be warned though - dishes are quite heavy so you will be full for many hours following the meal. Overall, good food and moderately pricey.., would go back.

UAUBd1q2AdhCgfzH44nwdw.text: Winding down a visit to London Royal Salute hosted a small dinner at the Chef's Table. A wonderful view of all the kitchen as they prepared all of the food. The service was impeccable and our host from the restaurant went above and beyond to accommodate our every want. The food? Amazing is the word that comes to mind. Savory, aromatic delightful all fit for this meal. I can't imagine a trip to London not including Benares.

6pxar3fb6I7H64gQUxPDvQ.text: Summary: for the price, the food quality could be much better. Full review: We arrived a bit early for our reservation and were seated in the bar in the meantime. The bartender was extremely friendly and made great, strong, drinks. If we were to return, it would probably be only for drinks.Once seated, the experience was one of refined elegance. The waitstaff did a great job, as expected for such an upscale restaurant.We both had the tasting menu and I opted for the wine pairing while my fiancée stuck with her drink from the bar.The stand-out course was the seared scallop, which was delicious. Everything else was executed well, but not impressive. In fact, the main course of lamb was dry and a bit tough - a grave error. There were two options for the wine pairing and I opted for the slightly less expensive of the two. All of the wines served were good, but nothing stood out enough to merit seeking out a bottle of the stuff. For the price we paid, we expected better in terms of food. Otherwise, the experience was average for this type of restaurant. Hence, we deduct one star from the average three to arrive at a final verdict of two.

8PrslBIY4DP1g4adUAfjDA.text: Disappointing. Really. When you are a highly recommended, Michelin Star, Indian restaurant in London people get excited. We made reservations weeks in advance, specifying the tasting menu for four at that time. When we arrived they had no idea we had confirmed the tasting menu in our reservation. Once the food began to arrive it looked lovely, but was completely lacking in creativity, depth, flavor and spice. The main course was lamb which was nicely grilled, but had raw masala on the meat. Many flavors felt more European than Indian. Have they attempted to reach a non-Indian audience with a compromise in their recipes? The service was the biggest weakness. A tasting menu comes with the expectation of discovery and flavor. We wanted to experience the breadth of food your chef has to offer but instead got a string of surprisingly similar grilled options. We often had no idea what we were being served (is that salmon on pink trout?) and the staff were preoccupied with others.  After our three hour fifteen minute meal we were sort of abandoned before they remembered our dessert. Then we had to ask for the check three times, finally hailing the manager in desperation. Pretty big disappointment after our anticipation of a Michelin Star experience meal. One of our guests actually said, "We should have ordered take out from our local Indian place, would have been better."

ciZcoMUViOTzttpFacWfOg.text: I was so excited to try Indian food in London being Indian myself. This Michelin rated restaurant was highly recommended to us by our hotel concierge. Although the restaurant only had three other tables seated, we were told we had to sit at one of two top tables because they would be getting busy Which we did not see even at the time we were leaving.The service was not worth a Michelin rated service and what we've come to expect when a restaurant is rated such as that. The service was sparse and slow and although we had told him that I was vegan, he ended up recommending dishes that had dairy which I had to tell him there was dairy in it. We ended up ordering an appetizer and a main which were all just very bland and almost seemed like they were curated with just the spices of india and lacked taste. I was so disappointed with the taste that most of the food was left on the plates. The English pea tiki was the best thing I had and it was just okay. The cauliflower had a raw masala taste and the potatoes which looked like it was taste phenomenal were so sad when it came to seasoning. Pretty to look at with no depth or flavor. That was the theme of the food. Although I appreciate that they had a gluten-free flatbread, the food was just not what I was expecting in London especially for a Michelin rated meal.

GIndwQRpNLknNf6MTMABqA.text: My Indian friend highly recommended this place as the best Indian food he's ever had. It's a very posh restaurant well deserving of the Michelin star. The service was very good and friendly. The food was amazing. Ingredients wee top notch and the seafood was really fresh and perfectly cooked. It really opened my eyes to high end Indian cuisine. To bad it can't be duplicated in LA. I'll be back the next time I'm in London for sure.

SZK9Y1nXMOeb6PAAQGIdZA.text: Wow! Definitely know why Benares has a Michelin Star. Dined solo around 9:15pm on a weekday and it was packed as I was getting seated so knew that was a good sign.I was pretty quickly brought the restaurants version of popped chips with 3 different chutneys. This was a great way to start off the meal (I was ravenous!) after ordering my appetizer and main, I was served an amuse bouche - pumpkin fritter with lemon dip underneath. This was delicious!Next up was the Jerusalem artichoke appetizer with paneer and parsnips with a romesco dip. This was absolutely to die for. The flavors went so well together. Wish I asked for a paired wine with this course. For the entree, the waiter suggested I try the most popular dish, which was the smoked tandoori lamb chops with a bold glass of red. These paired perfectly together. The lamb was SO tender. Wish there were more.Would love to do the tasting menu next time or try more dishes if dining with someone else.

Y_M8ozRVu7QMIrjJ1uIluA.text: My fiancée took me to Benares for dinner after he proposed to me so this restaurant has a very special in my heart. He's not a fan of Indian food, but he knows that I absolutely love Indian food! I loved their chicken tikka masala. I got it spicy but it wasn't spicy at all. The chef made it as spicy as possible but it was still not spicy. Regardless, it was absolutely delicious. It was the best chicken tikka masala I've ever had! Also, their butter chicken was fabulous! They have samosas on the vegetarian menu and they were so good! Get the mango lassi too! Omg. Everything was absolutely fabulous and perfect. I would highly suggest coming to Benares if you're ever in London! It's totally worth it. They also have very unique items on their menu that you won't be able to find at any other Indian restaurant in the world. They also brought us a beautiful dessert for our special day, but I'm sure that my fiancée called ahead of time. It's also very hard to get a reservation to this restaurant!

UaHovUjvQif16zVKrwMkLA.text: Other than the food, it was below our expectations. Great food; modest service (although nothing too formal, we asked for water which was never delivered etc.) and modest atmosphere. It missed a cosy "feel", potentially driven by the low ceiling, the lighting choices & the somewhat crammed seating.All of this for quite a premium price, driving the rating to 3.5 stars.

3u9XqZLtI71TYiUSA_ZrYg.text: The best meal I have ever eaten! Lots of nice little touches including spiced nuts with our fabulous cocktails, little popadoms to start, an amuse bouche, petit fours and a dessert for my birthday. I started with the scallops which were perfection, then I had the venison which came with delicious veg, rice and a chocolate curry! Followed by the refreshing strawberry semi freddo.Service was attentive but informal. £200 for 2 means I'll only be going back for a very special occasion, but the food really was outstanding. They serve a street food menu in the bar that is much more reasonable.. looking forward to giving that a go!

6acxxBNeg_oSMAkjyvz6Kg.text: The ambience at Benares is sleek and modern. Service could have been better considering this is a Michelin starred restaurant. We did not order wine and they left the glasses on the table for awhile until we asked them to be removed. When we asked for this, the waiter seemed oddly confused.Food wise, we enjoyed our meal. We tried a couple appetisers including the vegetarian sampler which was quite good. For the main, I had the seafood stir fry which was nicely spiced with a variety of seafood. The highlight of the night was a solo rider behind us getting sloshed and knocking over his table. It was a total mess with liquid and glass everywhere. Apparently he's a regular so beware if you are seated next to a man throwing back glasses of red wine!

JCAjHr_4NFXQwj2OGDuzXg.text: Excellent service and I thoroughly enjoyed my 2 course set-menu which started with some crispy prawns with raita, and a main course of the most delicate and tender chicken. The waiter explained that the chicken is left in yoghurt for some time to tenderize the meat.A quiet setting, seemed to have lots of business meetings.The only thing I would recommend is a refresh on the interior design but otherwise recommended.

6If46wT6FU0LgJocA84QBA.text: Overpriced for the experience offered. Bland food and very discourteous service. Owner especially is very rude and bigoted.

MoXi_TAV-rwOoMEAneccuw.text: For a Michelen starred restaurant the food was quite mediocre. The kofta was dry and the sauce didn't really help. The lamb was succulent buy very bland. I can think of half a dozen restaurants that would do better. For a £100 lunch for two, this was huge disappointment. Two stars because the starters were quite good, and the service was extremely attentive.

hU4Dmp0tgMeBcKbiJBF-9w.text: This is the most overrated restaurant. Overpriced with bland food. Turns out the Atul Kocchar is a bigot as well that makes derogatory marks about other faiths and cultures. His restaurant just got shut down at the JW Marriott in Dubai where I did unfortunately eat his rubbish food. Disgusting human being with bad food. Don't go here.

VG06JZjG8fY38NbJHoETFw.text: Had the chef's table, really nice private room with kitchen views. The service was spot on all night. We came late for dinner and ended up closing the place down. The food was very good, but I wouldn't say as good as other Indian spots with Michelin stars. Had some great port, which was very enjoyable.

SY7kW3l8HT4RQHOpiorTQQ.text: One of the best meals ever and the service to match.  Had a cocktail before sitting for dinner and the atmosphere was very nice from the start, with friendly and attentive staff. Dinner consisted of appetizers and shared dishes for the table.  The request for gluten free was taken care of nicely and there were several dishes.  The nan was for the rest of us and was delicious.  All memorable dishes, in particular the lamb.

-rM4Otc6Xhi8kk06ipF_BA.text: To be honest, this is the best Indian food I've ever had. The flavours are so complex, without being too spicy, where you need to drink so much water that it fills you up instead of the food. Staff is incredibly sociable and they create such an amazing environment. Wish there was a restaurant exactly like this in the Silicon Valley. Open one up, please! Go here. You will not regret it, but remember it as an experience for your taste buds and a joy to interact with everyone here!

-FH5v-loOFazoEnNV_OSCA.text: We had lunch at Benares and chose the set menu. All three dishes were perfect hence why I give Benares top marks!First you walk through a bright reception to then be taken to the more subdued bar area and then onto the dining room. All have a modern and sleek decor with an Indian touch.I started my meal with the bhatti spiced lamb pasanda, smoked aubergine puree and grilled gem lettuce. The lamb was tender and the spices just right, a lovely contrast with the very fresh grilled gem lettuce. For main I ordered the seam bream with kokum sauce and this was just wow! The fish was beautifully cooked and I could have licked my plate to waste none of this sauce! I finished my meal with the date and sticky pudding with bayleaf ice cream. One of the best sticky toffee pudding I've ever had and the bayleaf ice cream a revelation with this sugary dessert.

O752JOBZrshgLjRrBgOCNw.text: We paid around £100 per head, not including wine.  Frankly, I am surprised at the positive reviews.  Neither the food (some of it rather dank and one chicken dish utterly inedible) nor the service (inattentive waiters who do not know what is going on in the room and ignore customers) were remotely up to Michelin star standards.  I would not pay my own money in this place again.

wLgohlLfS1VYJpe9ZhGWUQ.text: Everything was unique .. Exotic and fabulous. Presentations was very nice as well. The also have a nice lounge/bar area. Specialty cocktails : Pomegranate Raspberry Caipiroska...

fVo9L4LL-2FZOqQLSeI8Cg.text: I've always wanted to eat in a Michelin restaurant and with my friend's recent 30th birthday party, I got the chance to. Benares delivers on all fronts, from the fantastic decor to the inventive cocktail menu to the food which is quite simply divine. The service is something I have never come across before and our party of approximately 50 people were taken care of as though we were royalty. The menu takes care of meat-eaters and vegetarians alike and there are some lovely combinations that you just have to try. The desert menu was also a lovely surprise with traditional Inidan treats like kulfi being reinvented and served. The price does make it a restaurant that the average person is more like to keep for a special occasion rather than weekly entertainment, but at no point did I feel ripped off. The value here is bestowed upon you from the second you set foot in the door. My tip is to always make reservations, but then also arrive 30 minutes earlier and spend some time in the bar area next to the lovely water features. You won't regret having a drink here!

84p5kUvq1OYP0XlVs8I6iA.text: top notch restauarantand pretheatre menu is a bargain
